content.html: As appears to be tradition for #ProjectWeirdLittleGuy here's a Monday #ScreenshotSaturday showing off... a crafting system! I wanted it to feel physical but also be super portable? So the result is a crafting bowl that goes in your inventory rather than a full bench that has to be actually built. And of course you hit it with a stick to do the actual crafting

photo.alt: A portrait orientation photography looking along a flat valley of vineyards flanked on either side by the gentle slopes of mountains. A dirt track leads from the foreground down below, along the valley floor. The sun is low and bathing the valley in soft golden light, making the mountains further back increasingly hazy, and making green and red sunspots on the lens. There's a tiny farmhouse surrounded by a copse of trees nestled on the valley floor.

content.html:
Thank you Tumblr
I needed to hear about relic English still living among us

ed: corrected tense
content.value: Thank you TumblrI needed to hear about relic English still living among used: corrected tense

photo.alt:
‚Äò Hal Sawyer - 2y ago (edited) : My favorite relic English still used everywhere is the word "the" used in phrases like: "the more | look at this, the stranger it seems', or "the bigger they come, the harder they fall". This "the" is not the article of any noun, itis a different word, a conjunction descended from the old English "pa", pronounced "tha" which means either "when" or "then". Back in early Middle English the structure "if - then" had not taken over and if you wanted to express an if - then relationship you said "pa whatever, pa whatever", meaning "when such-and- such, then such-and-such". "pa" sounds almost the same as "the" and the spelling of the two converged, but the meaning remained totally different. "the more, the merrier" literally means "when more, then merrier" or "if more, then merrier'; same as centuries ago.

e RE: TN 5] 5

content.html:
Why are ethics questions always like:
"is it ethical to steal bread to feed your starving family?"

And not:
"is it ethical to sell bread when families are starving?"

content.html: Anna's hummingbirds exceeded all my expectations. Amazing little creatures, full of character that viciously defended their feeding patches against conspecifics. Then, with a twist of the neck, their head became alive with the most incredible colour!
content.value: Anna's hummingbirds exceeded all my expectations. Amazing little creatures, full of character that viciously defended their feeding patches against conspecifics. Then, with a twist of the neck, their head became alive with the most incredible colour!

like there's companies like bethesda who also love their modders and will even hire from their modder pool, but then companies like nintendo who despise them üò´
